Lesson 3: Fine-Tuning Fee Structures and Achieving Full Enrollment

Image by storyset under Freepik

Once you’ve determined your base tuition rates, you’ll dive deeper into the many small and big opportunities to shape additional fee structures for your program and the services you offer. Alongside this process, you’ll likely conduct market research to better understand what similar programs are offering in your area. Engaging in this process will help you be competitive in the marketplace and more likely to achieve full enrollment.

Remember that tuition must cover costs for your business to be successful. There should also be additional funding to fill any gaps. How you structure your program to make this happen will change from year to year.

Balancing Tuition and Fees

The first place to start when fine-tuning tuition and fees is to look at different ways to balance them depending on your program’s unique needs.

Instructions: Select each dropdown below to go beyond base tuition and consider other areas within fees to increase income.

  • Administrative Fees

    Image by pressfoto under Freepik

    Registration fees: These are usually one-time or yearly fees that cover the cost of processing all the paperwork required for enrollment.

    Holding fees: A deposit or fee for reserving an enrollment space for a child is commonplace. This protects your business and ensures families are serious about enrolling in your program. If you hold a space and then the family cancels, you may not be able to fill that space quickly, therefore losing revenue you had been expecting. A holding fee can help bridge that gap.

  • Part-Time Fees

    Image by pikisuperstar under Freepik

    Many programs don’t offer part-time care because it doesn’t offer the same reliable income source as full-time care and it requires a lot more administrative work to juggle multiple families on different care schedules. Moreover, a part-time schedule can be difficult for some children that thrive on routine.

    Acknowledging these challenges to your program, it’s standard practice to charge higher daily rates for part‐time children. For example, increase your hourly rate by 20%-30% if you will only be caring for a child for 1-2 days per week.

    While you may prefer full-time enrollment, be open to adding part-time enrollments. It can help fill spaces in your program that would otherwise be empty. Moreover, the lower daily or hourly cost for full-time care may be all the incentive you need to get full-time enrollments.

  • Enrichment Fees

    Image by Yan Krukau under Pexels modified from the original

    Many programs arrange special activities for a fee during normal business hours. Examples can include enrichment programming like fitness or mindfulness training from a qualified coach, more individualized attention from a tutor, or playing games that increase cognitive development. These add-on fees are separate from base tuition, optional, and clearly defined in fee structures.

  • Materials Fee

    Image by Mikhail Nilov under Pexels

    Materials fees can be assessed yearly, quarterly, or bi-annually and usually go towards the cost of supplies. These are required and may be pro-rated. Be sure to include this information clearly in your fee schedule.

  • Add-On Care

    Image by freepik under Freepik

    If a need exists and you have the staffing to cover it, add on care can boost income, though it is not a reliable source of revenue like tuition is. Consider offering:

    • Night or weekend services: This can be an ongoing service or a monthly caregiver’s night out, for example. Be sure to include this in the fee structure so families know this is an available service and advertise with plenty of time to ensure you have the staff available to meet attendance.
    • Drop-in care: This is all dependent on available space in your program. If you are at capacity, parents will need to pre-arrange drop-in care as available. If your program has available space, it will be easier to accommodate families for drop-in care. Drop-in care fees are usually more expensive than regular tuition because programs cannot depend on this as a reliable source of income and benefit from the consistency of routine contract care.
  • Additional Fees

    Image by William Fortunato under Pexels modified from the original

    Late pick up fees: No matter what time your center closes, it’s important to hold parents accountable for picking their children up on time. Many child care centers do this by charging late pick up fees that heavily incentivize parents to pick their kids up on time. It’s not uncommon for a child care center to charge families a dollar or more for every minute they’re late picking up their child. Your program will have to pay additional staffing costs when families are late picking their children up and this can be costly, especially if staff need to be paid overtime wages.

    Late payment fees: This is a proactive step to encourage prompt tuition payment. When parents pay on time, it not only helps you keep cash flowing into your business, but it saves all the time that would need to be redirected into following up on payments and adjusting the budget.

Market Research

Image by rawpixel.com under Freepik

Whether it’s your program’s first year or fifteenth, you will want to complete an annual review of market needs by gathering information about child care programs in your area. Thoroughly knowing the market will help you decide what kind of programming to offer and how much you could charge for tuition.

For example, if your program price is much higher than comparable programs in your area, families may choose to enroll at a lower cost program. If your price is too low, you may not be able to cover the cost of your expenses or compensate your employees fairly. Beyond understanding how you compare to market rates, you will also need to consider increased costs from one year to the next.

Beyond helping you plan better financially, market research is a great way to see what other programs exist and get ideas and inspiration for your own program. You may want to gather your information using this graphic organizer.

Beware of Price Fixing

Image by jcomp under Freepik

Before you begin your market research, it’s important to understand the difference between market research and price fixing. Price fixing is an agreement among competitors to raise, lower, maintain, or stabilize prices. This can be an agreement that is written, verbal, or inferred from conduct. Price fixing is illegal. Potential penalties include imprisonment (up to ten years) and large fines up to $1 million for individuals, $100 million for companies, or twice the gain or loss from the offense.

Generally, the antitrust laws require that each company establish prices and other competitive terms on its own, without agreeing with a competitor. As you may already know, child care programs across the country regularly talk with each other about many topics, including fees, and, in some cases, are even unknowingly in violation of this law. For example, it is against the law for a child care director in a town or community to call another director within that same community and share plans to increase the program’s child care fees. Courts would likely view this as price fixing, and it is a violation of federal antitrust laws.

As a program director, there are legal ways to gain information for your market research. For example:

  • Contact your local Resource Center or local chapter of NAEYC. They may have rate information that is reported to them or that is publicly available.
  • Review rates in local child care program ads. These are sometimes also posted on Craigslist or in Classified Ads.
  • Check competitor websites and request information while refraining from conversations with other programs and administration about changing or “fixing” rates.
  • Avoid engaging in any sort of dialogue that could be seen as an agreement. When in doubt, err towards the side of caution. It’s okay to collect data. It’s not okay to collaborate on creating fee structures with other programs.

Scenarios

Instructions: For each scenario below, identify which are a good strategy for setting child care fees and which are not a good strategy. Using the dropdowns select Yes if it is a good strategy or No if it is not a good strategy. Select each Check Answer button to check your answers.

Image by peoplecreations under Freepik

You’re at a professional development conference in your community and start talking to some of the other administrators and directors of other child care centers. You are all struggling with one of the same dilemmas—your infant rooms are full and you have a waiting list, but still you are struggling to make ends meet on the budget every quarter. One administrator suggests that you raise your infant prices together. Since the demand is high, you might as well all start charging more for the limited spaces you have available. The extra income will let everyone have a little more cushion room on the budget, which is ultimately good for everyone. Is this a good strategy?


No, agreeing with a competitor to change your prices is an example of price fixing and it’s illegal. Remember, potential penalties include imprisonment (up to ten years) and large fines up to $1 million for individuals, $100 million for companies, or twice the gain or loss from the offense. Instead of setting prices together, collaborate with other programs on different ways you each earn additional income. Maybe one of your competitors hosted a successful pancake breakfast fundraiser and they are happy to share their learnings from it with you so that you can host your own. It’s okay to talk about the issues you have in common, but it’s not okay to price fix.

Image by jcomp under Freepik

After working tirelessly on different budget scenarios, you’ve finally established the bottom rate for your tuition to ensure that you at least break even. When you start researching other comparable programs in your area, you find that they are charging, on average, $2 more per hour for care. Using your budgeting tool, you raise all your tuition rates by $2/hour. You feel guilty raising the rates so much at first, but as you continue using your budgeting workbook, you realize that raising rates will allow you to offer income-based discounts and scholarship slots that you couldn’t otherwise afford. You will also be able to afford a small raise for all employees. You decide to go through with the $2/hour increase since it is in line with the market and will give your program space in the budget for quality improvements. Is this a good strategy?

Yes, this is a legally sound strategy that ensures your program can make enough money to sustain itself and continue offering quality services.

Image by freepik under Freepik

For years, your center has offered full-time care from 6 am-6 pm 5 days a week. Recently, you’ve seen a decline in early morning attendance. It’s been difficult to find staff to cover the early morning and late afternoon hours anyway, so you decide to overhaul the schedule and create a shorter base day schedule with an optional early bird and evening program. Base tuition will decrease and early bird and evening enrollment will be an extra cost commensurate with the increased cost to keep the program open for extended hours. With the financial commitment from parents that need extended care, you can more accurately gauge the staff required and create schedules that better accommodate the needs of everyone. Is this a good strategy?

Yes, this strategy uses strong analysis of your program’s specific constraints and needs. By changing your program this way, you ensure you can break even as a business and continue offering high-quality care to your families.

Image by gpointstudio under Freepik

An administrator from one of the child care centers across town calls to share with you their plan to raise enrollment and waiting list fees to make up for their budget shortfall. She knows your budget is always tight and thought it would be helpful for your program to match their fees. Since their fees sound reasonable for the amount of work it takes to run all the administrative processing for your center, too, you agree and raise your fees. Is this a good strategy?

No, this is another example of price fixing and it’s illegal. While it may be true that your budget is tight, you cannot agree to set prices with another competitor. Instead, consider analyzing your budget independently and deciding on different ways to bridge the gap in your budget. We’ve covered many different legal ways to troubleshoot this common issue. If you’re still stuck on what to do, reach out to a trained professional or consult with one of the many agencies built to help child care centers succeed.

Great Work!

Your improved knowledge around setting tuition and fees will help you offer a high-value program to families looking for quality care. This is an important step in achieving full enrollment.

Moreover, the same strategies that help you set your fees (considering best staffing, offering part-time and add-on care, etc.) add worth to your program and will also help you attract families and achieve full enrollment.
